newsitem.title: GERMANY: DGB union calls on German employers to create jobs.
newsitem.headline: DGB union calls on German employers to create jobs.

text.p: Germany's stubbornly high unemployment cannot be blamed on increased wage levels or lower company profits, the DGB trade union federation said on Saturday.
In a report focusing on profit and wage developments, the DGB said company earnings for two years had been as high as levels reached during times of full employment.
At the same time, wage levels relative to national income were at their lowest post-war point, while unit wage costs had remained unchanged for the last year.
German unemployment is currently running at 11.1 percent, or 4.26 million people.
"Employees have made great concessions. Now it is the turn of the employers to create training places and jobs," DGB board member Michael Geuenich said.
He said the government and the Bundesbank should also make efforts to contribute to pan-European employment policy.
The union federation said net wages, adjusted for inflation, had risen by just 0.1 percent in west Germany in 1996, and by 0.2 percent in east Germany.
West German wage levels last year were only 1.2 percent above 1980 levels, while corporate net profits had doubled over that period, it said.
